00022 /**
00023  * @file   RMA.cpp
00024  * @author Chuck Sugnet
00025  * @date   Mon May 16 13:30:37 2005
00026  * 
00027  * @brief Functions to implement Robust Multiarray Average. 
00028  *
00029  * Implements the method described in "Exploration, normalization, and summaries
00030  * of high density oligonucleotide array probe level data", Irizarry RA, Hobbs
00031  * B, Collin F, Beazer-Barclay YD, Antonellis KJ, Scherf U, Speed TP.,
00032  * Biostatistics. 2003 Apr;4(2):249-64.
00033  * 
00034  */

00060 /** 
00061  * Subtract the median off of each row.
00062  * 
00063  * @param psMatrix - matrix.
00064  * @param numRow - number of rows.
00065  * @param numCol - number of columns.
00066  * @param rowEffect - values to subtract from each row.
00067  */
00068 void RMA::subRowEffect(vector< vector<float> > &psMatrix, int numRow, int numCol, vector<float> &rowEffect) {
00069   int colIx = 0, rowIx = 0;
00070   /* some sanity checks. */
00071   assert(numRow > 0);
00072   assert(numCol > 0);
00073   
00074   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
00075     for(colIx = 0; colIx < numCol; colIx++) {
00076       psMatrix[rowIx][colIx] = psMatrix[rowIx][colIx] - rowEffect[rowIx];
00077     }
00078   }
00079 }
00080 
00081 /** 
00082  * Find the median for the rows.
00083  * 
00084  * @param psMatrix - matrix.
00085  * @param numRow - number of rows in matrix.
00086  * @param numCol - number of rows in matrix.
00087  * @param colEffect - fill in row effect.
00088  */
00089 void RMA::getRowEffect(vector< vector<float> > &psMatrix, int numRow, int numCol, vector<float> &rowEffect) {
00090   vector<float> row(numCol, 0.0);
00091   int colIx = 0, rowIx = 0;
00092   
00093   /* some sanity checks. */
00094   assert(numRow > 0);
00095   assert(numCol > 0);
00096   rowEffect.clear();
00097 
00098   /* loop through rows calculating effect for each one. */
00099   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
00100     /* fill in row for effect calculation. */
00101     row.clear();
00102     for(colIx = 0; colIx < numCol; colIx++) {
00103       row.push_back(psMatrix[rowIx][colIx]);
00104     }
00105     /* median of row is effect. */
00106     rowEffect.push_back((float)median(row.begin(), row.end()));
00107   }
00108 }
00109 
00110 /** 
00111  * Subtract the median off of each row.
00112  * 
00113  * @param psMatrix - matrix.
00114  * @param numRow - number of rows.
00115  * @param numCol - number of columns.
00116  * @param rowEffect - values to subtract from each row.
00117  */
00118 void RMA::subColEffect(vector< vector<float> > &psMatrix, int numRow, int numCol, vector<float> &colEffect) {
00119   int rowIx = 0, colIx = 0;
00120 
00121   /* some sanity checks. */
00122   assert(numCol > 0);
00123   assert(numRow > 0);
00124   
00125   for(colIx = 0; colIx < numCol; colIx++) {
00126     for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
00127       psMatrix[rowIx][colIx] = psMatrix[rowIx][colIx] - colEffect[colIx];
00128     }
00129   }
00130 }

00132 /** 
00133  * Find the median for the columns.
00134  * 
00135  * @param psMatrix - matrix.
00136  * @param numRow - number of rows in matrix.
00137  * @param numCol - number of columns in matrix.
00138  * @param colEffect - fill in column effect.
00139  */
00140 void RMA::getColEffect(vector< vector<float> > &psMatrix, int numRow, int numCol,  vector<float> &colEffect) {
00141   vector<float> col(numRow, 0.0);
00142   int rowIx = 0, colIx = 0;
00143   
00144   /* some sanity checks. */
00145   assert(numCol > 0);
00146   assert(numRow > 0);
00147   colEffect.clear();
00148 
00149   /* loop through cols calculating effect for each one. */
00150   for(colIx = 0; colIx < numCol; colIx++) {
00151     /* fill in col for effect calculation. */
00152     col.clear();
00153     for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
00154       col.push_back(psMatrix[rowIx][colIx]);
00155     }
00156     /* median of col is effect. */
00157     colEffect.push_back((float)median(col.begin(), col.end()));
00158   }
00159 }

00161 /** 
00162  * Return the sum of a matrix.
00163  * @param psMatrix - matrix.
00164  * @param numRow - number of rows in matrix.
00165  * @param numCol - number of columns in matrix.
00166  * 
00167  * @return sum of matrix.
00168  */
00169 double RMA::matrixSum(vector< vector<float> > &psMatrix, int numRow, int numCol) {
00170   double sum = 0.0;
00171   int rowIx = 0, colIx = 0;
00172   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
00173     for(colIx = 0; colIx < numCol; colIx++) {
00174       sum += fabs(psMatrix[rowIx][colIx]);
00175     }
00176   }
00177   return sum;
00178 }

00180 /** 
00181  * Static version of medianPolishSet for when it isn't convenient to 
00182  * have an RMA instance.
00183  * 
00184  * @param PM - Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00185  *             will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00186  *             here.
00187  * @param numRow - Number of rows in the matrix.
00188  * @param numCol - Number of columns in the matrix.
00189  * @param indexes - Indexes of the probes for probe set of interest
00190  *        into PM matrix.
00191  * @param results - Vector in which probe sets summaries, one per GeneChip,
00192  *        will be returned.
00193  *
00194 **/
00195 void RMA::medianPolishPsetFromMatrix(vector< vector<float> > &pmMatrix, int numRow, int numCol, 
00196                                      vector<float> &colEstimates, vector<float> &rowEstimates, bool doLog) {
00197   vector<float> colEffect(numCol, 0.0);
00198   vector<float> rowEffect(numRow, 0.0);
00199   vector<float> workBuff(max(numCol, numRow), 0.0);
00200   float totalEffect = 0;
00201   int maxIter = 10; // How many iterations to do. 
00202   int iterIx = 0;   // Current iteration number.
00203   int i = 0, j = 0; // Indexes into arrays.
00204   double epsilon = 0.01;
00205   double oldSum = 0.0, newSum = 0.0;
00206   float delta = 0.0;
00207 //  static bool first = true;
00208 //   if(first) {
00209 //     cerr.setf(ios::fixed, ios::floatfield);
00210 //     cerr.precision(10);
00211 //     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00212 //       for(j = 0; j < numCol; j++) {
00213 //         cerr << pmMatrix[i][j] << "\t";
00214 //       }
00215 //       cerr << endl;
00216 //     }
00217 //  }
00218   /* sanity checks. */
00219   assert(numRow > 0 && numCol > 0);
00220   assert(numRow <= (int)pmMatrix.size());
00221   assert((int)pmMatrix.size() > 0 && numCol <= (int)pmMatrix[0].size());
00222 
00223   /* Clear out the estimates. */
00224   colEstimates.clear();
00225   rowEstimates.clear();
00226   colEstimates.insert(colEstimates.begin(), numCol, 0);
00227   rowEstimates.insert(rowEstimates.begin(), numRow, 0);
00228 
00229   if(doLog) {
00230     /* Log transform. */
00231     float log_2=logf(2.0);
00232     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00233       for(j = 0; j < numCol; j++) {
00234           if(pmMatrix[i][j] <= 0.0){
00235             Err::errAbort("RMA::medianPolishPSetFromMatrix. Values must be strictly positive. "); 
00236           }
00237         pmMatrix[i][j] = logf(pmMatrix[i][j])/log_2;
00238       }
00239     }
00240   }
00241 
00242   // Here goes the polishing...
00243   for(iterIx = 0; iterIx < maxIter; iterIx++) {
00244 
00245   int k;
00246   if(maxIter == 9)
00247     k = 3;
00248 
00249 
00250     // Do the columns
00251     getColEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00252     subColEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00253     for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) 
00254       colEffect[i] += workBuff[i];
00255 
00256     delta = (float)median(rowEffect.begin(), rowEffect.end());
00257 
00258     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) 
00259       rowEffect[i] -= delta;
00260 
00261     totalEffect += delta;
00262 
00263     // Do the rows    
00264     getRowEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00265     subRowEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00266     
00267     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) 
00268       rowEffect[i] += workBuff[i];
00269 
00270     delta = (float)median(colEffect.begin(), colEffect.end());
00271 
00272     for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) 
00273       colEffect[i] -= delta;
00274     totalEffect += delta;
00275 
00276     // Check for convergance.
00277     newSum = matrixSum(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol);
00278     if(newSum == 0 || fabs(newSum - oldSum) < epsilon  * newSum) 
00279       break;
00280     oldSum = newSum;
00281   }
00282 
00283   /* data to return. */
00284   for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) {
00285     colEstimates[i] = totalEffect + colEffect[i];
00286   }
00287   for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00288     rowEstimates[i] = totalEffect + rowEffect[i];
00289   }
00290 //   if(first) {
00291 //     cerr.setf(ios::fixed, ios::floatfield);
00292 //     cerr.precision(10);
00293 //     first = false;
00294 //     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00295 //       cerr << rowEstimates[i] << "\t";
00296 //     }
00297 //     cerr << endl;
00298 //   }
00299 }

00302 /** 
00303  * Static version of medianPolish.  In this version precomputed values are used as seed values to the usual 
00304  * median-polish algorithm.  It is allowed to run until the usual convergence criterion are met. 
00305  * 
00306  * 
00307  * @param PM - Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00308  *             will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00309  *             here.
00310  * @param numRow - Number of rows in the matrix.
00311  * @param numCol - Number of columns in the matrix.
00312  * @param indexes - Indexes of the probes for probe set of interest
00313  *        into PM matrix.
00314  * @param results - Vector in which probe sets summaries, one per GeneChip,
00315  *        will be returned.
00316  */
00317 
00318 void RMA::medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsUsedAsSeedValues(vector< vector<float> > &pmMatrix, int numRow, int numCol, 
00319                                      vector<float> &colEstimates, vector<float> &rowEstimates, bool doLog) {
00320   vector<float> colEffect(numCol, 0.0);
00321   vector<float> rowEffect(numRow, 0.0);
00322   vector<float> workBuff(max(numCol, numRow), 0.0);
00323   float totalEffect = 0;
00324   int maxIter = 10; // How many iterations to do. 
00325   int iterIx = 0;   // Current iteration number.
00326   int i = 0, j = 0; // Indexes into arrays.
00327   double epsilon = 0.01;
00328   double oldSum = 0.0, newSum = 0.0;
00329   float delta = 0.0;
00330   /* sanity checks. */
00331   assert(numRow > 0 && numCol > 0);
00332   assert(numRow <= (int)pmMatrix.size());
00333   assert((int)pmMatrix.size() > 0 && numCol <= (int)pmMatrix[0].size());
00334 
00335   /* Clear out the estimates. */
00336   rowEstimates.clear();
00337   rowEstimates.insert(rowEstimates.begin(), numRow, 0);
00338 
00339   if(doLog) {
00340     /* Log transform. */
00341     float log_2=logf(2.0);
00342     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00343       for(j = 0; j < numCol; j++) {
00344           if(pmMatrix[i][j] <= 0.0){
00345             Err::errAbort("RMA::medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsUsedAsSeedValues. Values must be strictly positive. "); 
00346           }
00347         pmMatrix[i][j] = logf(pmMatrix[i][j])/log_2;
00348       }
00349     }
00350   }
00351   bool firstTime = true;
00352   // Here goes the polishing...
00353   for(iterIx = 0; iterIx < maxIter; iterIx++) {
00354 
00355     // Do the columns
00356     if(firstTime == true){
00357       firstTime = false;
00358       for(i=0; i<numCol; i++)
00359         workBuff[i] = colEstimates[i];
00360     } else{ 
00361       getColEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00362     }
00363     subColEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00364     for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) 
00365       colEffect[i] += workBuff[i];
00366 
00367     delta = (float)median(rowEffect.begin(), rowEffect.end());
00368 
00369     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) 
00370       rowEffect[i] -= delta;
00371 
00372     totalEffect += delta;
00373 
00374     // Do the rows    
00375     getRowEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00376     subRowEffect(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, workBuff);
00377     
00378     for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) 
00379       rowEffect[i] += workBuff[i];
00380 
00381     delta = (float)median(colEffect.begin(), colEffect.end());
00382 
00383     for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) 
00384       colEffect[i] -= delta;
00385     totalEffect += delta;
00386 
00387     // Check for convergance.
00388     newSum = matrixSum(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol);
00389     if(newSum == 0 || fabs(newSum - oldSum) < epsilon  * newSum) 
00390       break;
00391     oldSum = newSum;
00392   }
00393 
00394   /* data to return. */
00395   for(i = 0; i < numCol; i++) {
00396     colEstimates[i] = totalEffect + colEffect[i];
00397   }
00398   for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
00399     rowEstimates[i] = totalEffect + rowEffect[i];
00400   }
00401 }

00406 /**
00407  * Static version of medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffects.  This version does the last steps of the usual
00408  * median-polish algorithm but does not iterate until convergence. If the feature effects that are used 
00409  * have been generated from the same data on which the analysis is done, the chip effect values will not
00410  * change.  
00411  *
00412  * @param pmMatrix -            Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00413  *                              will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00414  *                              here.
00415  * @param numRow -              Number of rows in the matrix.
00416  * @param numCol -              Number of columns in the matrix.
00417  * @param colEstimates -        This is the precomputed vector of probe (feature) effects.
00418  * @param rowEstimates -        This is the output vector of chip effects.
00419  * @param doLog -               This is a boolean switch to turn on or off the computation of logs of the input matrix.
00420  */
00421 
00422   void RMA::medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsOnePass(vector< vector<float> > &pmMatrix, int numChips, int numProbes,
00423                                 vector<float> &colEstimates, vector<float> &rowEstimates, bool doLog){
00424 
00425     // In this function we subtract off the precalculated feature effects (colEstimates) from the pmMatrix,
00426     // calculate the medians of the remaining rows, and to these medians, add the median of the precalculated
00427     // feature effects.  These are the last steps in the original medianPolish algorithm.  
00428 
00429     if(doLog) {
00430       float log_2=logf(2.0);
00431       for(int i = 0; i < numChips; i++) {
00432         for(int j = 0; j < numProbes; j++) {
00433           if(pmMatrix[i][j] <= 0.0){
00434             Err::errAbort("RMA::medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsOnePass. Values must be strictly positive. "); 
00435           }
00436           pmMatrix[i][j] = logf(pmMatrix[i][j])/log_2;
00437         }
00438       }
00439     }
00440 
00441     rowEstimates.clear();
00442 
00443     subColEffect(pmMatrix, numChips, numProbes, colEstimates);
00444     getRowEffect(pmMatrix, numChips, numProbes, rowEstimates);
00445     float delta = (float)median(colEstimates.begin(), colEstimates.end());
00446 
00447     vector<float>::iterator begin = rowEstimates.begin();
00448     vector<float>::iterator end = rowEstimates.end();
00449     for(; begin!=end; begin++){
00450       *begin += delta;
00451     } 
00452   }

00455 /** 
00456  * Compute the mean of a given vector.
00457  * sum(column)/n
00458  * @param dat - vector of doubles to take average of.
00459  * @return - mean value of vector
00460  */
00461 double RMA::vectorMean(vector<float> &dat) {
00462   double sum = 0;
00463   unsigned int i = 0;
00464   for(i = 0; i < dat.size(); i++) {
00465     sum += dat[i];
00466   }
00467   return sum / dat.size();
00468 }
00469 
00470 
00471 /** 
00472  * Compute the variance of a given column. 
00473  * (sum(average - actual))^2 / n-1
00474  * @param dat - vector of doubles to take variance of.
00475  * @return - variance of vectorn
00476  */
00477 double RMA::vectorVariance(vector<float> &dat) {
00478   double mean = 0;
00479   double sumOfSquares = 0;
00480   unsigned int i = 0;
00481   
00482   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00483 
00484   mean = vectorMean(dat);
00485   for(i = 0; i < dat.size(); i++) {
00486     sumOfSquares += (mean - dat[i]) * (mean - dat[i]);
00487   }
00488   return sumOfSquares / (dat.size() - 1);
00489 }
00490 
00491 /** 
00492  * Return the value at a particular quantile, Example quantile
00493  * would be .5 which is equivalent to the median.
00494  * 
00495  * @param dat - Data of interest.
00496  * @param quantile - Quantile of interest to report between [0,1];
00497  * @return value at quantile.
00498  */
00499 double RMA::vectorQuantile(vector<float> &dat, double quantile) {
00500   vector<float> copy(dat);
00501   int i = 0;
00502   double r, f, result;
00503 
00504   /* Check to make sure there is something in the vector. */
00505   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00506 
00507   /* Check for size == 1 where can't do i+1. */
00508   if(dat.size() == 1)
00509     return dat[0];
00510 
00511   std::sort(copy.begin(), copy.end());
00512 
00513   /* Find the indexes of interest. */
00514   r = (dat.size() - 1) * quantile;
00515   i = (int)floor(r);
00516   f = r - i;
00517 
00518   result = ((1 - f) * copy[i]) + (f * copy[i+1]);
00519   return result;
00520 }
00521   
00522 /** 
00523  * Return the range of values from .75 quantile to .25 quantile.
00524  * 
00525  * @param dat - Data of interest.
00526  * @return - difference between .75 and .25 quantiles.
00527  */
00528 double RMA::vectorIqr(vector<float> &dat) {
00529   double lowQuant = vectorQuantile(dat, .25);
00530   double highQuant = vectorQuantile(dat, .75);
00531   return highQuant - lowQuant;
00532 }
00533 
00534 /** 
00535  * Find the minimum value in a vector.
00536  * 
00537  * @param dat - vector of data.
00538  * 
00539  * @return minimum value.
00540  */
00541 double RMA::vectorMin(vector <float> &dat) {
00542   unsigned int i = 0;
00543   float minimum = -1;
00544   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00545   minimum = dat[0];
00546   for(i = 0; i < dat.size(); i++) {
00547     minimum = min(minimum, dat[i]);
00548   }
00549   return minimum;
00550 }
00551 
00552 /** 
00553  * Find the maximum value in a vector.
00554  * 
00555  * @param dat - vector of data.
00556  * 
00557  * @return maximum value.
00558  */
00559 double RMA::vectorMax(vector <float> &dat) {
00560   unsigned int i = 0;
00561   float maximum = -1;
00562   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00563   maximum = dat[0];
00564   for(i = 0; i < dat.size(); i++) {
00565     maximum = max(maximum, dat[i]);
00566   }
00567   return maximum;
00568 }
00569 
00570 /** 
00571  * Implementation of the bw.nrd0() function in R to decide kernel
00572  * bandwidth.
00573  * 
00574  * @param dat - vector of data of interest.
00575  * @return - Bandwidth of kernel to use.
00576  */
00577 double RMA::findBandWidth(vector<float> &dat) {
00578   double bandWidth = 0;
00579   double high = 0, low = 0;
00580   assert(dat.size() > 1);
00581   high = sqrt(vectorVariance(dat));
00582   low = min(high, vectorIqr(dat)/1.34);
00583   if(!(fabs(low) > 0)) {
00584       Verbose::out(1, "In RMA::findBandWidth, boundary condition hit. Possible problem with input data.");
00585       low = high;
00586   }
00587   if(!(fabs(low) > 0)) {
00588       Verbose::out(1, "In RMA::findBandWidth, boundary condition hit. Possible problem with input data.");
00589       low = fabs(dat[0]);
00590   }
00591   if(!(fabs(low) > 0)) {
00592       Verbose::out(1, "In RMA::findBandWidth, boundary condition hit. Possible problem with input data.");
00593       low = 1.0;
00594   }
00595   assert(low);
00596   bandWidth = .9 * low * pow(1.0*dat.size(), -0.2);
00597   return bandWidth;
00598 }
00599 
00600 /** 
00601  * Spread the mass around our histogram bins.
00602  * 
00603  * @param dat - data of interest.
00604  * @param bandWidth - Bandwidth of mass distribution.
00605  * @param yVec - vector of bins to spread mass into. 
00606  * @param numBins - number of bins in yVec. 
00607  */
00608 void RMA::colMassDist(vector<float> &dat, double bandWidth, double from, 
00609                       double to, vector<float> &yVec, int numBins) {
00610   double xDelta = 0;
00611   double ixMin = 0;
00612   double ixMax = numBins - 2;
00613   double ixMass = 0;
00614   double minimum, maximum;
00615   int i = 0;
00616   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00617 
00618   ixMass = 1.0 / dat.size();
00619   
00620   maximum = vectorMax(dat);
00621   minimum = vectorMin(dat);
00622   from = minimum - 7 * bandWidth;
00623   to = maximum + 7 * bandWidth;
00624 
00625   xDelta = (to - from) / (numBins -1);
00626   for(i = 0; i < 2*numBins; i++)
00627     yVec[i] = 0;
00628 
00629   for(i = 0; i < (int)dat.size(); i++) {
00630     double xpos = (dat[i] - from) / xDelta;
00631     int ix = (int)floor(xpos);
00632     double fx = xpos - ix;
00633     if(ixMin <= ix && ix <= ixMax) {
00634       yVec[ix] += (float)(1 - fx);
00635       yVec[(ix+1)] += (float)fx;
00636     }
00637     else if(ix == -1) {
00638       yVec[0] += (float)fx;
00639     }
00640     else if(ix == ixMax + 1) {
00641       yVec[ix] += (float)(1 - fx);
00642     }
00643   }
00644 
00645   for(i = 0; i < numBins; i++)
00646     yVec[i] *= (float)ixMass;
00647 }
00648 
00649 /** 
00650  * Convolves the real numbers in two vectors. Fill in kerelwords with
00651  * the convolved data. Note that yVec and kernel words must be a size
00652  * which is a power of two (i.e. 256, 512, 1024, etc. )
00653  * 
00654  * @param yVec - binned up data.
00655  * @param kernelWords - kernel function.
00656  * @param count - Number of entries in yVec and kernelWords. 
00657  */
00658 void RMA::convolveDataKernel(vector<float> &yVec, vector<float> &kernelWords, int count) {
00659   vector<float> y(2*count,0.0);
00660   vector<float> k(2*count,0.0);
00661   vector<float> r(2*count,0.0);
00662   int cCount = 2 * count; /* Count for storing as complex type for fft. */
00663   int i = 0;
00664 
00665   /* Check to make sure we have a power of two. */
00666   assert(yVec.size() > 0);
00667   /// @todo This check looks ok, but on some hardware very small deviations make the floor and ceil fail
00668   ///  assert(floor(log((double)yVec.size()) / log(2.0)) == ceil(log((double)yVec.size()) / log(2.0)));
00669 
00670   /* Get data ready for fft call. */
00671   for(i = 0; i < count; i++) {
00672     y[i*2] = yVec[i];
00673     y[i*2+1] = 0;
00674     k[i*2] = kernelWords[i];
00675     k[i*2+1] = 0;
00676   }
00677 
00678   fft(y, false);
00679   fft(k, false);
00680 
00681   /* multiply results to convolve. */
00682   for(i = 0; i < cCount; i+=2) {
00683     r[i] = y[i] * k[i] + y[i+1] * k[i+1];
00684     r[i+1] = y[i+1]*k[i] - y[i]*k[i+1];
00685   }
00686   
00687   fft(r, true);
00688 
00689   for(i = 0; i < count; i++) {
00690     kernelWords[i] = r[2*i]; /* Pull out the real numbers as result. */
00691   }
00692 }
00693 
00694 /** 
00695  * Find the interpolation for value d between x and y. Assumes
00696  * that x and y are sorted.
00697  * 
00698  * @param d - value to interpolate.
00699  * @param x - vector 1
00700  * @param y - vector 2
00701  * 
00702  * @return interpolation of d from x into y. 
00703  */
00704 double RMA::linearInterpolate(double d, vector<float> &x, vector<float> &y) {
00705   int start = 0, end = 0, mid = -1;
00706   double value = 0, yRange = 0, xRange = 0;
00707   
00708   assert(x.size() > 0 && y.size() > 0);
00709   end = int(x.size()) - 1;
00710   /* Check edge cases. */
00711   if(d < x[start]) 
00712     return y[start];
00713   if(d > x[end])
00714     return y[end];
00715   
00716   /* Do a binary search for values. */
00717   while( start + 1 < end ) {
00718     mid = (start + end) / 2;
00719     if(d > x[mid]) {  /* pick larger half of vector for further search */
00720       start = mid;
00721     }
00722     else { /* pick smaller half of vector for further search. */
00723       end = mid;
00724     }
00725   }
00726   assert(start+1 == end);
00727 
00728   /* Exact match? */
00729   if(d == x[start]) 
00730     return y[start];
00731   if(d == x[end])
00732     return y[end];
00733   
00734   yRange = y[end] - y[start];
00735   xRange = x[end] - x[start];
00736   value = y[start] + yRange * ((d - x[start])/xRange);
00737   return value;
00738 }
00739 
00740 /** 
00741  * Linearly interpolate x and y using values in x out. 
00742  * 
00743  * @param x - vector 1 for interpolation from.
00744  * @param y - vector 2 for interpolation to.
00745  * @param xOut - vector with data to interpolate.
00746  * @param yOut - output vector for interpolated data.
00747  */
00748 void RMA::linearApprox(vector<float> &x, vector<float> &y, 
00749                        vector<float> &xOut, vector<float> &yOut) {
00750   const size_t size = x.size();
00751   size_t i = 0;
00752 
00753   assert(x.size() > 0 && y.size() > 0 && xOut.size() > 0);
00754   assert(x.size() == y.size());
00755 
00756   for(i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00757     yOut[i] = (float)linearInterpolate(xOut[i], x, y);
00758   }
00759 }
00760 
00761 void RMA::printVector(vector<float> &dat) {
00762   unsigned int i = 0;
00763   for(i = 0; i < dat.size(); i++) {
00764     cerr << dat[i] << ", ";
00765   }
00766   cerr << endl;
00767 }
00768 
00769 void RMA::printArray(float *dat, int size, float thresh){
00770   int i = 0;
00771   for(i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00772     if(fabs(dat[i]) >= thresh) 
00773       cerr << dat[i] << ",";
00774   }
00775   cerr << endl;
00776 }
00777 
00778 void RMA::printArray(double *dat, int size, double thresh){
00779   int i = 0;
00780   for(i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00781     if(fabs(dat[i]) >= thresh) 
00782       cerr << dat[i] << ",";
00783   }
00784   cerr << endl;
00785 }
00786 
00787 
00788 double RMA::arrayMax(double *d, int count) {
00789   double m = d[0];
00790   int i =0;
00791   for(i = 0; i < count; i++) {
00792     m = max(m, d[i]);
00793   }
00794   return  m;
00795 }
00796 
00797 /** 
00798  * Fill in a vector from a given column of data. 
00799  * 
00800  * @param PM - Matrix to fill in from.
00801  * @param numRows - Number of rows in matrix, will be vector length.
00802  * @param colIx - Column number to create vector from.
00803  * @param toFill - Vector to fill in with column data. 
00804  */
00805 void RMA::columnToVector(double **PM, int numRows, int colIx, vector<float> &toFill) {
00806   int i = 0;
00807   assert(PM != NULL && numRows > 0);
00808   assert(toFill.size() == 0); // This vector should be empty when we get it. 
00809   toFill.reserve(numRows);    // avoid reallocation for efficiency.
00810   for(i = 0; i < numRows; i++) {
00811     toFill.push_back((float)PM[i][colIx]);
00812   }
00813 }
00814     
00815 /** 
00816  * Here we are recreating the density() function in R with an
00817  * Epanechnikov kernel. There are three
00818  * steps 1) Compute a Epanechikov kernel. 2) Convolve the mass
00819  * distribution with a fast fourier transform. 3) Linearly interpolate
00820  * the results.
00821  * @param dat - data of interest.
00822  * @param numBins - number of bins to spread data over (16384 for original
00823  *                  RMA method).
00824  * 
00825  * @return - Mode of the data.
00826  */
00827 double RMA::modeOfData(vector<float> &dat, 
00828                        int numBins) {
00829   double bandWidth = 0;
00830   vector<float> yVec(2 * numBins, 0.0);
00831   vector<float> kernelWords(2 * numBins, 0.0);
00832   double from, to, maximum, minimum, upper, downer;
00833   vector<float> xords(numBins, 0.0), xOut(numBins, 0.0), 
00834     output(numBins, 0.0), kernelWordsVec(numBins);
00835   int i = 0;
00836   int maxIx = 0;
00837   double width = 0;
00838   double mode = 0;
00839 
00840   assert(dat.size() > 0);
00841   bandWidth = findBandWidth(dat);
00842   maximum = RMA::vectorMax(dat);
00843   minimum = RMA::vectorMin(dat);
00844 
00845   /* Set the limits. */
00846   from = minimum - 7 * bandWidth;
00847   to = maximum + 7 * bandWidth;
00848   downer = from + 4 * bandWidth;
00849   upper = to - 4 * bandWidth;
00850 
00851   /* Spread the mass of the distribution around. */
00852   colMassDist(dat, bandWidth, from, to, yVec, numBins);
00853 
00854   for(i = 0; i < numBins * 2; i++) {
00855     kernelWords[i] = float(i * (2*(to - from))/(numBins*2-1));
00856   }
00857   for(i = numBins+1; i < numBins * 2; i++) {
00858     kernelWords[i] = float(-1.0 * kernelWords[numBins - (i - numBins)]);
00859   }
00860 
00861   /* Apply the epanechnikov kernel. */
00862   width = bandWidth * sqrt(5.0);
00863   for(i = 0; i < numBins * 2; i++) {
00864     double abKw = fabs(kernelWords[i]);
00865     double abKwSq = (1.0 - (abKw/width * abKw/width));
00866     if(width > abKw) 
00867       kernelWords[i] = float(.75 * abKwSq / width);
00868     else
00869       kernelWords[i] = 0;
00870   }
00871 
00872   /* Use a fast fourier tranform to combine kernel and data. */
00873   convolveDataKernel(yVec, kernelWords, 2*numBins);
00874 
00875   /* Set the range for the interpolation. */
00876   for(i = 0; i < numBins; i++) {
00877     xords[i] =  float(from + i * ((to - from) / (numBins -1)));
00878     xOut[i] = float(downer + i * ((upper - downer) / (numBins-1)));
00879     kernelWordsVec[i] = kernelWords[i] / numBins;
00880   }
00881 
00882   /* interpolate. */
00883   linearApprox(xords, kernelWordsVec, xOut, output);
00884 
00885   /* Find bin with the most weight, i.e. the mode. */
00886   maximum = output[0];
00887   maxIx = 0;
00888   for(i = 0; i < numBins; i++) {
00889     if(maximum <= output[i]) {
00890       maximum = output[i];
00891       maxIx = i;
00892     }
00893   }
00894   
00895   mode = xOut[maxIx];
00896   return mode;
00897 }
00898 
00899 /** 
00900  * Calculate the parameters necesary to do the RMA background 
00901  * subtraction.
00902  * @param data - all of the data for a given cel file.
00903  * @param mu - pointer to parameter mu to be filled in by function.
00904  * @param sigma - pointer to parameter sigma to be filled in by function.
00905  * @param alpha - pointer to paramter alpha to be filled in.
00906  * @param numBins - number of bins to use in denstiy. RMA traditionally uses
00907  *                  16,384. It is essential that this number be a power of two.
00908  */
00909 void RMA::estimateBgParam(vector<float> &data, double *mu, 
00910                           double *sigma, double *alpha, int numBins) {
00911 
00912   vector<float> upper, lower; // For upper and lower quantiles.
00913   double mode = 0, expMean = 0;
00914   double upperSum = 0, lowerSum = 0;
00915   unsigned int i =0, upperCount = 0, lowerCount = 0;
00916   assert(data.size() > 0 && mu != NULL && sigma != NULL && alpha != NULL);
00917   assert( (int)Util::round(pow(2.0, Util::round(log((double)numBins) / log(2.0)))) == numBins);
00918   
00919   /* Get the mode of all the data. */
00920   mode = modeOfData(data, numBins);
00921 
00922   /* Get the data in the lower .5 quantile. */
00923   for(i = 0; i < data.size(); i++) {
00924     if(data[i] < mode) {
00925       lower.push_back(data[i]);
00926     }
00927   }
00928   
00929   mode = modeOfData(lower, numBins);
00930   lower.clear();
00931   
00932   /* Divide out into above background and below background. */
00933   for(i = 0; i < data.size(); i++) {
00934     if(data[i] < mode) {
00935       double tmp = data[i] - mode;
00936       lower.push_back((float)tmp);
00937       lowerSum += (tmp * tmp);
00938       lowerCount++;
00939     }
00940     else {
00941       double tmp = data[i] - mode;
00942       upper.push_back((float)tmp);
00943       upperSum += (tmp * tmp);
00944       upperCount++;
00945     }
00946   }
00947   expMean = modeOfData(upper, numBins);
00948   (*alpha) = 1 / expMean;
00949   (*mu) = mode;
00950   (*sigma) = sqrt((double)lowerSum/(lowerCount - 1)) * sqrt(2.0);
00951 }
00952 
00953 /** 
00954  * The cdf function for standard normal distribution.
00955  * @param x - value.
00956  * @return - probability that standard normal value has
00957  * probability <= x.
00958  */
00959 double RMA::PHI(double x) {
00960   return pnorm(x);
00961 }
00962 
00963 /** 
00964  * Standard normal probability density function.
00965  * @param x - value of interest.
00966  * @return - density at value supplied
00967  */
00968 double RMA::phi(double x){
00969   double pi = 3.14159265358979323846; 
00970   return 1 / sqrt(2 * pi)* exp(-0.5 * x * x);
00971 }
00972 
00973 /** 
00974  * Cumulative normal density function.
00975  * @param u - value for which to calculate the distribution function.
00976  * @return - probability that value is < u.
00977  */
00978 double RMA::pnorm(double u)
00979 {
00980   const double a[5] = {
00981     1.161110663653770e-002,3.951404679838207e-001,2.846603853776254e+001,
00982     1.887426188426510e+002,3.209377589138469e+003
00983   };
00984   const double b[5] = {
00985     1.767766952966369e-001,8.344316438579620e+000,1.725514762600375e+002,
00986     1.813893686502485e+003,8.044716608901563e+003
00987   };
00988   const double c[9] = {
00989     2.15311535474403846e-8,5.64188496988670089e-1,8.88314979438837594e00,
00990     6.61191906371416295e01,2.98635138197400131e02,8.81952221241769090e02,
00991     1.71204761263407058e03,2.05107837782607147e03,1.23033935479799725E03
00992   };
00993   const double d[9] = {
00994     1.00000000000000000e00,1.57449261107098347e01,1.17693950891312499e02,
00995     5.37181101862009858e02,1.62138957456669019e03,3.29079923573345963e03,
00996     4.36261909014324716e03,3.43936767414372164e03,1.23033935480374942e03
00997   };
00998   const double p[6] = {
00999     1.63153871373020978e-2,3.05326634961232344e-1,3.60344899949804439e-1,
01000     1.25781726111229246e-1,1.60837851487422766e-2,6.58749161529837803e-4
01001   };
01002   const double q[6] = {
01003     1.00000000000000000e00,2.56852019228982242e00,1.87295284992346047e00,
01004     5.27905102951428412e-1,6.05183413124413191e-2,2.33520497626869185e-3
01005   };
01006   register double y, z;
01007 
01008   y = fabs(u);
01009   if (y <= 0.46875*M_SQRT2) {
01010     /* evaluate erf() for |u| <= sqrt(2)*0.46875 */
01011     z = y*y;
01012     y = u*((((a[0]*z+a[1])*z+a[2])*z+a[3])*z+a[4])
01013       /((((b[0]*z+b[1])*z+b[2])*z+b[3])*z+b[4]);
01014     return 0.5+y;
01015   }
01016   z = exp(-y*y/2)/2;
01017   if (y <= 4.0) {
01018     /* evaluate erfc() for sqrt(2)*0.46875 <= |u| <= sqrt(2)*4.0 */
01019     y = y/M_SQRT2;
01020     y = ((((((((c[0]*y+c[1])*y+c[2])*y+c[3])*y+c[4])*y+c[5])*y+c[6])*y+c[7])*y+c[8])
01021         /((((((((d[0]*y+d[1])*y+d[2])*y+d[3])*y+d[4])*y+d[5])*y+d[6])*y+d[7])*y+d[8]);
01022     y = z*y;
01023   } else {
01024     /* evaluate erfc() for |u| > sqrt(2)*4.0 */
01025     z = z*M_SQRT2/y;
01026     y = 2/(y*y);
01027     y = y*(((((p[0]*y+p[1])*y+p[2])*y+p[3])*y+p[4])*y+p[5])
01028       /(((((q[0]*y+q[1])*y+q[2])*y+q[3])*y+q[4])*y+q[5]);
01029     y = z*(M_1_SQRTPI-y);
01030   }
01031   return (u < 0.0 ? y : 1-y);
01032 };
01033 
01034 /** 
01035  * RMA background correct subtraction. The RMA bacground subtraction
01036  * is a little complicated. The details are available in Ben Bolstad's
01037  * thesis dissertation:
01038  * http://stat-www.berkeley.edu/users/bolstad/Dissertation/Bolstad_2004_Dissertation.pdf
01039  * The basic idea is that the signal is exponential and the background
01040  * is additive gaussian. There are a lot of fun integrals to show that
01041  * the joint distribution can be found to estimate the true signal
01042  * given the observed signal on the chip and the parameters mu and
01043  * sigma for the background and alpha for the exponential. Estimating
01044  * mu, sigma and alpha explicitly is difficult though so RMA uses an
01045  * ad-hoc method where mu is estimated as the mode of the data, sigma
01046  * is estimated by the variation in the lower 50% quantile tail and
01047  * alpha is estimated as an exponential fit to the upper 50% quantile
01048  * tail. The "true" signal is then estimated as:
01049  * 
01050  * X = a + b(phi(a/b)/PHI(a/b))
01051  * where a = signal - mu - (sigma^2 * alpha)
01052  *       b = sigma
01053  
01054  *       phi and PHI are standard normal density function and
01055  *       distribution function respectively given as:
01056  *
01057  *       phi(z) = 1 / sqrt(2*pi) * exp(-.5*z^2)
01058  *       PHI(z) = \int_-inf^z 1 / sqrt(2*pi) exp(-.5w^2) dw
01059  * 
01060  * Note that this all happens on a per chip basis.
01061  * @param data - vector of data for a chip. 
01062  * @param numBins - number of bins to use for estimating mode
01063  *    of data for background parameters. Must be a power of 2.
01064  */
01065 void RMA::backgroundCorrect(vector<float> &data, int numBins) {
01066   double mu = 0, sigma = 0, alpha = 0;
01067   unsigned int i;
01068   assert(data.size() > 0);
01069   estimateBgParam(data, &mu, &sigma, &alpha, numBins);
01070   bool error = false;
01071   for(i = 0; i < data.size(); i++) {
01072     data[i] = bgSubData(data[i], mu, sigma, alpha, error);
01073     if(error) {
01074        Err::errAbort("RMA::backgroundCorrect() - error in background calculation");
01075     }
01076   }
01077 }
01078 
01079 /** 
01080  * Do a fast fourier transform on data using the Danielson-Lanczos
01081  * algorithm. Values in data vector will be overwritten with the
01082  * results. The format of data must be that of real and imaginary
01083  * numbers interleaved together. So if the real portion of the number
01084  * is at index 0, the imaginary portion will be at index 1. The next
01085  * real number is at index 2 and imaginary portion is at index 3,
01086  * etc. The input data vector must be a power of two (i.e. 32, 64,
01087  * 128, etc) if your data is not a power of two in length you must pad
01088  * it with zeros. Be warned that this bit of code is not terribly user
01089  * friendly and can be tough to work with.
01090  * 
01091  * @param data - data of interest with interleaving real and imaginary
01092  * portions.
01093  * @param doInverse - should we perform the inverse fourier transform?
01094  */
01095 void RMA::fft(vector<float> &data, bool doInverse)
01096 {
01097   int length = 0, next = 0, step = 0;
01098   int i = 0, j = 0, k = 0;
01099   double sinHalfTemp = 0, sinTemp = 0, theta = 0;
01100   double wr = 0, wi = 0, wpr = 0;
01101   double realTmp = 0, imagTmp = 0;
01102   int sign = 1;
01103 
01104   /* Sanity checks */
01105   assert(data.size() > 0);
01106 /// @todo This check looks ok, but on some hardware very small deviations make the floor and ceil fail
01107 //   if(!(floor(log((double)data.size()) / log(2.0)) == ceil(log((double)data.size()) / log(2.0))))
01108 //     Err::errAbort("RMA::fft() - data must be a power of two!");
01109 
01110   /* Are we calculating the inverse transform? */
01111   if(doInverse)
01112     sign = -1;
01113   
01114   /* Bit reversal. */
01115   j = 1;
01116   length = data.size();
01117   for (i = 1; i < length; i+= 2) {
01118     if (j > i) {
01119       realTmp = float(data[j-1]); data[j-1] = data[i-1]; data[i-1] = float(realTmp);
01120       realTmp = float(data[j]); data[j] = data[i]; data[i] = float(realTmp);
01121     }
01122     k = length / 2;
01123     while (k >= 2 && j > k) {
01124       j -= k;
01125       k /= 2;
01126     }
01127     j += k;
01128   }
01129 
01130   /* Danielson-Lanczos algorithm */
01131   next = 2;
01132   while (length > next) {
01133     step = next * 2;
01134     theta= sign * (6.28318530717959 / next); // Note that 6.28318530717959 is 2 * pi
01135     sinTemp = sin(theta);
01136     sinHalfTemp = sin(0.5 * theta);
01137     wpr = -2.0 * sinHalfTemp * sinHalfTemp;
01138     wr = 1.0;
01139     wi = 0.0;
01140     for (i = 1; i < next; i += 2) { 
01141       for (j = i;j <= length; j += step) {
01142         k = j + next;
01143         realTmp = wr * data[k-1] - wi * data[k];
01144         imagTmp= wr * data[k] + wi * data[k-1];
01145         data[k-1] = float(data[j-1] - realTmp);
01146         data[k] = float(data[j] - imagTmp);
01147         data[j-1] += (float)realTmp;
01148         data[j] += (float)imagTmp;
01149       }
01150       sinHalfTemp = wi;
01151       wi = wi * wpr + wr * sinTemp + wi;
01152       wr = wr * wpr - sinHalfTemp * sinTemp + wr;
01153     }
01154     next = step;
01155   }
01156 }
01157 
01158 struct _rmaPair 
01159 /** Utility structure for sorting by data, but
01160     remembering rank. */
01161 {
01162   double data; ///< intensity value.
01163   int rank;    ///< rank compared to other intensity values in chip.
01164 };
01165 
01166 /** 
01167  * Sort based on data in _rmaPair structure.
01168  * @param v1 pointer to _rmaPair structure.
01169  * @param v2 pointer to _rmaPair structure.
01170  * 
01171  * @return -1 if v1 < v2, 1 if v1 > v2, 0 if equal.
01172  */
01173 static int pairCompare(const void *v1, const void *v2){
01174   struct _rmaPair *p1, *p2;
01175   p1 = (struct _rmaPair *)v1;
01176   p2 = (struct _rmaPair *)v2;
01177 
01178   if (p1->data < p2->data)
01179     return -1;
01180   else if (p1->data > p2->data)
01181     return 1;
01182   else
01183     return 0;
01184 }
01185 
01186 
01187 /** 
01188  * Get the ranks of _rmaPair structures using the same algorthim as R
01189  * to break ties.
01190  * @param pairs - array of _rmaPair strucutres.
01191  * @param count - size of array.
01192  * @param ranks - vector of ranks.
01193  */
01194 void RMA::getRanks(struct _rmaPair *pairs, int count, vector<int> &ranks) {
01195   int current = 0, mark = 0;
01196   ranks.clear();
01197   while(current < count) {
01198     double total = 0;
01199     int i = 0;
01200     mark = current;
01201     while(mark < count -1 && pairs[mark].data == pairs[mark+1].data) {
01202       mark++;
01203     }
01204     total = floor((double)(mark + current + 2) / 2);
01205     for(i = 0; i < mark - current + 1; i++) {
01206       ranks.push_back((int)total);
01207     }
01208     current = mark + 1;
01209   }
01210 }
01211         
01212 
01213 /** 
01214  * Quantile Norm data using same algorithm to break ties as RMA
01215  * This function is deprecated as normalization sdk module now supports
01216  * bioconductor style quantile normalization.
01217  * @param data - matrix of data.
01218  */
01219 void RMA::quantileNorm(vector< vector<float> > &data) {
01220   struct _rmaPair **rmaMatrix = NULL;
01221   vector<float> avgs;
01222   vector<int> ranks;
01223   int i = 0, rowIx = 0, colIx = 0;
01224   int numRow = (int)data.size();
01225   assert(numRow > 0);
01226   assert(data[0].size() > 0);
01227 
01228   /* There are issues with how affy sdk and bioconductor 
01229      break ties in the sorting. Here we are going to step into
01230      c-style qsort() and R version rank() to break ties to ensure
01231      compatability with bioconductor version of code. */
01232 
01233   /* Allocate memory. */
01234   rmaMatrix = new struct _rmaPair*[numRow];
01235   if(rmaMatrix == NULL) 
01236     Err::errAbort("RMA::quantileNorm() - Out of memory.");
01237   
01238   for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
01239     rmaMatrix[i] = new struct _rmaPair[data[i].size()];
01240     if(rmaMatrix[i] == NULL) 
01241       Err::errAbort("RMA::quantileNorm() - Out of memory.");
01242   }
01243 
01244   /* Fill in data. */
01245   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
01246     for(colIx = 0; colIx < (int)data[rowIx].size(); colIx++) {
01247       rmaMatrix[rowIx][colIx].data = data[rowIx][colIx];
01248       rmaMatrix[rowIx][colIx].rank = colIx;
01249     }
01250   }
01251 
01252   /* Sort everything. */
01253   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
01254     qsort(rmaMatrix[rowIx], data[rowIx].size(), sizeof(struct _rmaPair), pairCompare);
01255   }
01256 
01257   /* Roll through and take the averages. */
01258   for(colIx = 0; colIx < (int)data[0].size(); colIx++) {
01259     double avg = 0.0;
01260     for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
01261       avg += rmaMatrix[rowIx][colIx].data / numRow;
01262     }
01263     avgs.push_back((float)avg);
01264   }
01265   for(rowIx = 0; rowIx < numRow; rowIx++) {
01266     getRanks(rmaMatrix[rowIx], data[rowIx].size(), ranks);
01267     for(colIx = 0; colIx < (int)data[0].size(); colIx++) {
01268       data[rowIx][rmaMatrix[rowIx][colIx].rank] = avgs[ranks[colIx]-1];
01269     }
01270   }
01271 
01272   for(i = 0; i < numRow; i++) {
01273     delete [] rmaMatrix[i];
01274   }
01275   delete [] rmaMatrix;
01276 }
